driven by Bond's companion . Along with its driver, it meets an untimely demise when pushed into a lake by .

white version is seen landing at Zorin's villa, bringing Stacey Sutton to its premises.
Max Zorin's first a larger airship. It is used for conferencing facilities, where Zorin first proposes the Main Strike plan.

Max Zorin's second, a much smaller blimp. It was intended to be used for Zorin to watch the destruction of Silicon Valley, but with that plan thwarted was a getaway vehicle that meets its end on the Golden Gate Bridge.

after escaping henchmen Bond is picked up by Tiffany Case in this car while in Las Vegas; Bond uses it to elude the Las Vegas Police.
Bond is seen early in the movie driving a yellow Stag to Amsterdam, while posing as diamond smuggler Peter Franks.
The car Bond has when Leiter tries to survey Tiffany Case at the funfair. Also used by some of Whyte Electronics security that chase down Bond after he escapes the lab.
the blue-white cars used by the Las Vegas Police. Black ones are later used by Felix Leiter and the CIA agents, when they search the house where Willard Whyte is imprisoned at.
first appear as cars driven by Whyte Electronic security. Later appear as the black-white cars of the Las Vegas Police.
the Slumber Inc hearse that picks up Bond and takes him to the funeral parlor.
Bond commandeers an all-terrain vehicle after he ditches the moon buggy.
Used by Bond to escape from the laboratory. Fast but infamously fragile, one of its wheels can be seen rolling past the camera position as Bond drives by it during the escape.
the mobile crane at Blofeld's Baja oil rig. Used by Bond to wreck Blofeld's Bathosub and destroy the control center for the diamond satellite.
first appears when piloted by diamond smuggler Joe. Later in the film, armed variants are used by US military to siege Blofeld's Baja Oilrig.
Willard Whyte's personal helicopter. Appears during the siege on Blofeld's Baja Oilrig.
used by US military to siege Blofeld's Baja Oilrig.

cruise ship at the end of the movie.

Classic automobile briefly driven by Bond during his visit to . A homage to ''Dr. No'' when Bond drives a 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air, a classic Ford was used in the film since FoMoCo vehicles (including those from Ford's Premiere Automotive Group) were extensively used.

A convertible driven by , the car was extremely similar in almost every way to a James Bond automobile. The vehicle includes a gatling gun, thermal imaging capabilities, mortar bombs, rockets under the front grille, miniature missiles hidden in the door, and front ramming spikes.

Although only on screen for a short period of time, the vehicle was marketed as a Bond car. In fact Ford created a special "007 edition" of the car. In Bond spirit, only 700 were made. Jinx drives the 2002 Ford Thunderbird up to Graves ice palace. It's unknown what type of gadgets, if any, were installed.

the Switchblade is essentially a one-man glider shaped like a fighter jet. It features retractable wings that control the speed and trajectory of the craft. Fitted with the same material on a stealth bomber, the switchblade allows Bond and Jinx to enter North Korea undetected.
used by Bond to fly to England to try find Gustav Graves.
this aircraft is used to transport Gustav Graves' equipment out of Iceland. It is later used as Graves' airborne command centre during the Icarus attack on the .
vehicle transporting Van Bierk to Colonel Moon's base. It is hijacked by Bond and his accomplices to use to go instead of Van Bierk. Destroyed by Colonel Moon's XM29 "Tank Buster".
No description available

Bond drives to Miss Taro's home in the Blue Mountains; he is pursued by Dr. No's thugs driving a LaSalle hearse. In the novel version, Bond drives the car that formerly belonged to Commander Strangways, the murdered agent in Kingston. It is also driven by Quarrel.

When 007 arrives in Jamaica, this was the first car Bond was a passenger in; however, the car was stolen, as depicted later in the film. It is driven by a chauffeur known only as "Mr Jones" who is in fact an agent of Dr. No.
Operated by the .

A modified swamp buggy with dragon camouflage and armor plating. The dragon tank was employed by Dr. Julius No to keep inquisitive locals away from his operations on Crab Key. It is equipped with a forward-firing flame thrower.

this vehicle was cosmetically similar to the S1, but mechanically different, as it exhibited no submarine capabilities. It was most notable for its remarkable security system, which detonated and destroyed the car when  broke the driver's window in an attempt to force entry into the car. Q Branch provided a second Turbo to Bond - in bronze instead of white - later in the movie.

A tiny but seemingly indestructible (rental) car belonging to  that Bond uses to make a "fast" getaway after Melina assassinates , who murdered her parents. The car used in the movie was allegedly fitted with a Citroën GS 4-cylinder boxer engine (in place of the standard 2-cylinder boxer), to make it able to outrun the two Peugeot 504s in pursuit.
used by Gonzales' henchmen to chase down the Citroën 2CV driven by Bond and Melina.
a Silver Wraith II is owned by Aris Kristatos and takes Bond and the Countess Lisl home from the casino.
Locque's personal car, which he uses to drive to Hector Gonzales' villa and later attempts to escape the Albanian warehouse with, only to die inside it when Bond kicks it off the cliff.
Locque, Kriegler, Claus and other henchmen use a dark red Mercedes-Benz 200 D facelift model when hunting James Bond in Cortina d'Ampezzo.
used by the assassins that attack Bond at Cortina d'Ampezzo.
used by Locque and other hitmen to try kill Bond and Lisl on the beach.
appears during the fight at the Ice Hockey rink.
appears during Spain chase.
appears during Spain chase.
appears during Spain chase.
helicopter that's guided indirectly by the "Mystery Assailant" to try kill Bond after the latter visits the graveyard.

the helicopter General Gogol and his bodyguards arrive to St. Cyril's Monastery with. <small>(Note: these copters were made by the Polish "PZL-Świdnik" for Soviet Union and its client states.)</small>
used by Gonzales to gun down the Havelocks.
used by Bond and Melina to go to wreck of St. Georges. Later gets attacked by a Mantis submarine operated by one of Kristatos' underlings.
used by one of Kristatos' underlings to attack Bond and Melina in their Neptune sub.

clandestine British electronic surveillance ship, disguised as an innocuous-looking Maltese fishing trawler. It housed the ATAC and gets scuttled by a seamine set by Kristatos' henchmen. Later in the film, Bond and Melina scuba dive inside it to retrieve ATAC.
No description available

Columbo's yatch. Bond its taken aboard after Lisl is killed on the beach.

Contrary to the films, James Bond's official car in the  novels was a grey 1933 Bentley convertible. The car featured a 4.5 litre engine with the Amherst-Villiers supercharger. In the novels, no gadgets were installed as this was Bond's personal vehicle that in ' is mentioned as being a hobby that Bond enjoys working on. Its only armament, in the novels, is a high power revolver Bond keeps in the glove compartment. The novel version of the Bentley Mark IV was destroyed during a chase sequence in '. The Bentley is also seen in ''From Russia with Love''. In the movie, the only gadget known to be included was a car phone. The film version of ''Goldfinger'' strongly implies that the Bentley was issued to Bond by Q-Branch
No description available

Used by . First appears when it brings Rosa Klebb to the . After Bond and Tatiana get out of the train, SPECTRE operatives use a UH-12 to try chase them down. It is destroyed when Bond snipes the co-pilot with his AR-7, who had pulled a sock of an grenade, causing the co-pilot to drop it inside and exploding the helicopter.
Driven by one of Kerim's sons, who picks Bond from Yesilköy Airport and chauffeurs him to Kerim's location.
It is used by Bulgarian spies to track Bond through Istanbul. It is later stolen by Red Grant to follow Bond.
pick-up truck guarded by , that was meant to be Red Grant's getaway vehicle. It is instead hijacked by Bond and Tania.

Boats used during the last action sequence near Trieste. Bond and Tania steal one with bunch of barrels attached on the rear, with SPECTRE henchmen soon arriving with Huntress 23 boats with black decals.

The most famous Bond car of all, it came with all the usual Q-Branch refinements which have been copied from movie to movie including bulletproof front and rear panels, oil slick, smoke screen, machine guns, rotating licence plates, telescoping tire slashers, tracer-receiving console and most famously, the passenger ejector seat.

Owned by Auric Goldfinger, it was used to smuggle gold by recasting all of the body panels in gold and shipping it from place to place. Often mistakenly called the "Phantom 337" as that is what Connery said in the film. If the car was actually called the "337," Connery probably would have spelled out "three-three-seven," as the British commonly do.

Tilly Masterson is seen driving a white Mustang - the convertible is totaled after Bond shreds the tires and lower rocker panels. This was the first appearance of a Mustang in a feature film. Other Fords were seen in the film, including a Ranchero and a Lincoln Continental.
Two 190/W121 cars are used to chase down Bond's DB5 at Goldfinger's Factory in Switzerland.
Oddjob is a passenger in a grey 220 SE during the car chase at Goldfinger's Factory in Switzerland.
the type of aircraft used by the members of . They are used to (falsely) spread the Delta 9 Nerve Gas upon Fort Knox and the surrounding area.
Car driven by  to take  to the nearby junkyard and kill him there. The car is subsequently crushed into a cube with Solo's body inside.
posing as an army ambulance, it is used to bring the  to Fort Knox to cut through the armored shutters.
Used as Auric Goldfinger's private jet. It is later disguised as a United States Air Force C-140 transport to kidnap Bond while Goldfinger makes his escape.
limousine in which Bond, Leiter and Sharkey ride to Leiter's wedding, before DEA informs them of Sanchez's presence in Bahamas.
limousine that's bringing Della to the church.
used by Sanchez and his thugs at Alvarez's hideout.
Bond's rental car in Key West.
the armored van that is used to transport Sanchez before Kilifer reveals his true colors.
the car Bond is chauffeured around Isthmus City by Q with.
No description available
used by Sanchez's henchmen at Paso El Diablo.
used by Perez and some other henchmen at Paso El Diablo. It carries the Stinger missiles Perez tries to destroy Bond's truck with. It gets crushed by Bond's truck.
cart that brings Pam to Joe Butcher at the Olympatec.
Sanchez has four of these trucks leave his plant after Bond destroys the place. Bond eventually hijacks one.
tank used by Heller and the Isthmusian soldiers to siege the safe house of the Hong Kong narcotics agents.
operated by the United States Coast Guard in the pre-title sequence. James Bond later uses the helicopter to trap escaping Sanchez's Cessna 172.
Used by Sanchez to travel between his villa and the Olympatec Meditation Institute.
used by Sanchez to arrive to Bahamas.
Sanchez uses one to try escape Bond and Felix during the pre-title sequence.
Floatplane hijacked by Bond during the Wavekrest sequence.
A crop dusting plane flown by  in pursuit of 's cocaine-filled Tankers. It is crippled by a stinger surface-to-air missile during the chase sequence.
midget submarine operated by Milton Krest's Wavekrest Marine Research. Its supposedly unused, when in reality, its was used to for Franz Sanchez's operations.
motorboat used by Bond to arrive to Barrelhead Bar and then later escape it with Pam Bouvier.
the motorboat used by Lupe to leave Sanchez's villa to help Bond covertly leave.

marine research vessel operated by Milton Krest. Bond sneaks aboard this ship a couple of times during the story. <small>(This vessel was called "State Point" when movie was filmed, and current goes by "J.W. Powell".)</small>
When Bond arrives in Rio de Janeiro, he is seen as a passenger in a blue Silver Wraith II which takes him to his hotel.
No description available
one is piloted by Corrine to bring Bond to Drax's Estate in California.
In the pre-titles sequence, Bond is almost left stranded on this aircraft with no pilot and no instruments, until he is pushed out with no parachute by Jaws.
No description available
No description available
used by Drax's sentries during the Amazon river chase.

"Moonraker" is a brand name applied to a space shuttle orbiter design, built by Drax Industries for NASA. Though the actual Space Shuttle had not flown by the time ''Moonraker'' was released, the Drax Moonraker is identical in design. These were named Moonraker 1-6.
Appears in the pre-title sequence, where it was driven by James Bond and his colleague Bianca. It is used to tow a horsebox, which secretly contains the AcroStar/Bede BD-5J inside.

Bond commandeers this Soviet Army staff car to pursue Octopussy's train. When the tires are shredded by a spikestrip, Bond turns onto the railway line and drives the car along the rails until he escapes just before the car is knocked into the river by an oncoming train.

After falling from Octopussy's train and hitching a lift in a Volkswagen Beetle, Bond steals this car to make the last stage of his journey to the US Air Force Base. West German police BMW 5 Series pursue Bond after his theft of the vehicle. Interestingly, sharp eyes will spot that this is a GTV 6 Quadrifoglio, the highest specification Alfa Romeo available, and widely considered the finest of these cars, as well as the fastest.
No description available
cars used by West German police to chase down Bond after he has stolen the Alfa Romeo.

vehicle: Rolls-Royce Phantom II Sedanca de Ville
sequence: Kamal Khan's car in India
boarded by Gen. Orlov to chase Bond after he has stolen the Mercedes-Benz with the stolen jewels aboard.
used by group of assassins trying to kill Bond and Vijay during the Tuk-Tuk chase.
the truck used by South American troops to escort Bond out of the base. After Bond gets free and boards the Range Rover, he shoots its wheels to stop it from chasing him down.
motorcycle used by West German police

Two of these basic auto rickshaws are used in a chase sequence through the streets of Udaipur - Bond and fellow MI6 agent  being in one, with  and his henchmen in the pursuing vehicle. It is insinuated that the auto-wallah driven by Vijay has been modified by MI6 as the tone of the engine becomes more like a motorcycle and Vijay performs a wheelie, exclaiming "This is a company car!"
two models appear; a red one that brings Orlov to Khan's palace and a green one that brings Gogol to the demolished Mercedes-Benz.
Kamal Khan's private aircraft. Bond grips onto the aircraft during take off and, after a fight with Gobinda atop the Twin Beech, rescues Octopussy before it crashes.

The Acrostar was used to escape from a mission in the opening sequence. The wings and nosecone section of this plane fold up vertically while not in use allowing it to be stored in small compartments (in this case a horse trailer).
A Union-Jack emblazoned Hot Air Balloon, used by Q and Bond to storm 's palace. It is equipped with CCTV cameras.

This car is seen in the movie in six scenes: in the pre-credits teaser, outside Bond's hotel, in the parking area at Draco's Birthday celebration, when he arrives at M's home (Quarterdeck), briefly outside a jeweler's shop, and as Bond & Tracy's wedding car. Nothing is known about what kind of gadgets are installed, except for a rifle with a telescopic sight mounted in the glovebox. Obviously, given what happens at the end, it does not have bulletproof glass.
owned by Tracy Di Vincenzo and features prominently in Bond's escape from Piz Gloria.
used in the drive-by-shooting that claims Tracy's life at the end of the film, with Blofeld driving it and Irma Bunt shooting an M16 rifle from the backseat through the open passenger window.
used by Irma Bunt, Bond and a few guards to travel from Lauterbrunnen to Piz Gloria's helipad.
used by Draco and his men to siege Piz Gloria at the climactic battle.

a convertible, which was later "winterised" with a hardtop. Came with all the usual refinements including side skis, spiked tires, missiles, hubcap-mounted lasers, rocket propulsion and a self-destruct mechanism.
munitions truck used by the Imposter 00 to try escape Gibraltar.
Austrian-registered 200 quattro Exclusiv C3 is used as a getaway car after General Koskov's defection at the start of the film. Later at Tangiers, Bond drives a 200 Avant quattro C3.
the milk float that is stolen by Necros in order to gain access to Blayden House.
used by the Czechoslovakian troops during the Aston Martin chase. <small>(These cars are actually Lada 1600/VAZ-2106 but with Lada 1500/VAZ-2103 bumpers and grilles)</small>
driven by the two female CIA agents in Tangiers. Bond tries to hitch a ride with them to evade the police, but ends up being taken to Felix Leiter's spy vessel.
the ground conveyor that Bond uses in Afghanistan to jump over the fence.

used by Kara to race inside the Hercules. Then, after they are forced to abandon the Hercules, Bond and Kara use this to parachute out of the aforementioned cargo plane. After landing, Bond decides to drive to Karachi.
Soviet Army vehicle that is used by both General Koskov and Necros to try chase down the Hercules.
two of them pursue Mujahadeen fighters across the bridge that ends up being destroyed by the Bomb thrown by Bond out of the Hercules.

medical helicopter used by Koskov's collaborators to sprit him away from the Blayden House. <small>(The helicopter used in the movie is in-fact a UH-1 that was captured by the British during the Falklands War and then sold to private use.)</small>
this V/STOL aircraft is used to evacuate Koskov after his defection to the west.

two different C-130 planes appear in the film. One is a RAF plane used by the 00 agents to parachute to Gibraltar. The second one is employed by Koskov/Whitaker's drug operation, which ends up being stolen by during the siege at the Soviet Airbase in Afghanistan. The second plane is doubled by Fairchild C-123 Provider in the scene where Bond and Necros fight each other while dangling on a web.
the aircraft that lands on the Soviet airbase just to crash at the WC 51 that Koskov is driving.
CIA intelligence gathering vessel. Bond meets Felix Leiter aboard it.

sequence: used to initially to clean and check the natural gas pipeline from USSR to West Europe. It's converted here specially to smuggle a man out of the Eastern bloc, with Koskov being the first.

Bond steals this car in Thailand, unknowing that Sheriff J.W. Pepper was in it looking to test drive it. It was used for the famous corkscrew jump, a computer-designed stunt that was captured in one take.

sequence: Including all of the usual Q refinements, this car was equipped with surface to air missiles. The main feature of the car however was the ability to transform into a submarine. Once transformed it could unleash depth charges and smoke screens. The car was nicknamed ''Wet Nellie'', a reference to the autogyro provided by Q for Bond's use in ''You Only Live Twice''.
used by Stromberg's thugs (+ Jaws) to pursue Bond on a highway in . Bond sprays grease on the windshield where the car runs off the road.
Van used by Jaws, who tricks Bond and Anya to sneak in the van, only for Jaws to take them to the pillars where he tries to kill them.
used by the motorcycle assassin trying to kill Bond and Anya while they drive the Lotus Esprit on the roads of Sardinia.
Royal Navy helicopter that Bond travels in to arrive in the meeting with the British officials.

an Bell 206 is owned by Karl Stromberg. When Bond begins investigating his affairs, chopper pilot  is dispatched to assassinate him from the air. A chase sequence across the Italian island of Sardinia ensues, culminating in Bond's  being driven off the end of a pier into the sea. Unaware of its sub-aquatic abilities, Naomi was eliminated by a surface to air missile launched by the car.
Royal Navy helicopter that brings Bond and Amasova to the USS Wayne.

Loaded with several Q refinements including ground to air missiles, a key chain that can control the car remotely, and as R proudly points out, cup holders. For films, this is the first car Bond is given by Q-branch where the steering wheel is on the left side.

Bond's legendary DB5 makes a couple camoes early in the film. First seen at the Oxford university and Bond subsequently uses it to drive to the Ministry of Defence headquarters.

used in , the car has a security system disallowing access without first being disarmed via the mobile telephone; the glove box security system is fingerprint-controlled. Armament includes sunroof rockets, deployable caltrops (out of the rear bumper), re-inflatable tyres, and a wire-cutter hidden under the BMW logo on the hood. The car may be remotely operated via Bond's mobile phone. The vehicle itself is actually a 740i model re-badged as a 750.
the car that passages M, Bond and Moneypenny at streets of London.
one of the cars used by Carver's henchmen at the Hamburg multistorey car park sequence. Gets exploded by the LAW-80 rocket launcher.

stolen in Saigon, the BMW R1200 motorcycle was used in a chase sequence through the city and was ridden by both James Bond and  of the .

light attack jet at the arms bazaar that's carrying two Soviet SB-5 nuclear torpedoes. Bond hijacks it to get it out of the terrorist hands and prevent the incoming Royal Navy cruise missile from exploding the L-39's nuclear payload.

used by Helga Brandt, it is later used by her to trap Bond and crash the plane to kill him.

the submarine that picks up Bond after the fake funeral. At the end of the film, it surfaces right on the spot where Bond's and Kissy's raft is.

the second American space capsule. Bond destructs the Bird 1 before its able to snatch it.
built by , the Bird One spacecraft was designed to kidnap American and Soviet orbital vehicles, engulfing the target craft and returning it to SPECTRE's hidden launch site in Japan.
